proposals.reasoning: Alice + Charlie has the broadest support as a low-drama, low-assumption starting pair. Most players (Bob, Eve, Frank, Grace, and myself) explicitly called this combination reasonable or preferred, and even those suggesting alternatives treated it as acceptable. This team lets us get an early read without prematurely committing to or ‘locking in’ more contested players like Grace, while also avoiding loudly self-promoting picks. The wide consensus should also make the vote patterns and reactions to this team informative for future missions.

votes.comment: As a known-good to myself, the only risk is Charlie; this is a broadly supported, low-drama Mission 1 team that should give useful info without overcommitting, so I’m fine sending it.
Broad consensus on Alice + Charlie, low-risk info-gathering first mission with no obvious red flags in the discussion.
First mission, low-info two-person team with broad consensus; including myself gives us an early read without overcommitting to contested players.
Team avoids the most contested/spotlight players and is broadly supported, making it a reasonable low-risk, information-gathering first mission.
Broad consensus and low-information first team; rejecting it without cause would draw unnecessary suspicion.
Low-risk first mission with no evil players on it; letting it pass gives useful info and keeps suspicion away from me and Grace early.
Sticking with the broad-consensus, low-drama first team avoids drawing suspicion and gives us useful voting and mission info early.

discussion.content: Since it’s only two people, I’d rather start with players who’ve been calm and consistent so far—I'd be fine with something like me and Bob, but I’m very wary of putting anyone who’s been pushing too hard to be included this early.

I’m okay with a cautious start, but I don’t love auto-including the leader just because they’re leader—if we’re doing a two-person team, I’d lean toward pairs that aren’t loudly campaigning for themselves, like maybe Alice and Grace or Alice and Charlie, and see how that result looks.

I like the idea of a low-drama pair to start, so Alice plus someone who hasn’t been angling hard either way—Grace or Diana both seem reasonable to me. If we really want to avoid putting the leader on automatically, I’d lean Alice + Grace as a good testing combo.
I’d rather avoid locking in someone like Grace this early when most of the push has been toward including her without much to go on—Alice with Charlie or Alice with me feels like a safer first read.

I’d rather not treat “quiet” as automatically trustworthy—of the options floated, I slightly prefer Alice + Charlie, since that gives us a decent baseline without hard-committing to someone like Grace this early. If that gets too much pushback, Alice + Diana seems like a fine backup.

I’m on board with keeping it low-drama and not overcommitting to anyone who’s been subtly pushed, so Alice + Charlie feels like the cleanest starting pair to me. If people really hate that, Alice + Diana is a reasonable fallback.

I’m fine with Alice + Charlie as a low-information, low-drama start, as long as we all agree not to over-clear either of them based on just one mission result. If that gets oddly contested, I’d be curious who pushes hardest against it and why.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1 was clean with Alice and Charlie, so keeping that pair together for now gives us the best current anchor while still not assuming they’re both confirmed good off a single result. As leader I’ll add myself as the third so the table gets information on a new player without breaking up the only successful combo we’ve seen. This keeps risk relatively low for Mission 2 while still expanding our knowledge, and we can rotate in more new players on later missions once we learn how this lineup behaves.

votes.comment: First mission with Alice+Charlie was clean; keeping that pair and adding one new player is a solid low-risk way to expand info on a second mission.
We shouldn’t auto-keep both Alice and Charlie after just one clean mission; splitting them and adding more new players gives better info and reduces the risk of a protected evil pair.
First mission with Alice and me was clean; keeping that pair and adding Diana (who I see as Merlin/Morgana) gives strong info with reasonable risk for Mission 2.
Keeps the only proven-clean pair together and adds exactly one new player without including any particularly suspicious names yet.
I’m not on it and there’s a high chance at least one evil is in Alice/Charlie/Diana, so I want this to go through and see what happens.

This keeps the same proven pair together and adds a relatively uncontroversial third, which risks another clean mission without giving much new alignment info or involving different, less-tested players.
Too safe a lineup around the clean Alice–Charlie pair; I’d rather see a team that tests more new players so we get broader info instead of reusing the same core.

discussion.content: Given the first mission was clean with just me and Charlie, I’m inclined to trust Charlie for now, but we shouldn’t assume both of us are definitely good just off one success. I’d like the next team to include at least two of Alice/Charlie plus one of the quieter players so we start getting more info.

I like keeping at least one of Alice/Charlie on the team since the first mission was clean, but we definitely shouldn’t lock both of them in every time. For this one I’d suggest, say, Alice plus two others (maybe me and one of Diana/Frank/Grace) so we can start spreading info around.
I’m okay trusting the Alice+me result for now, but I’d really like to add exactly one of Diana or Grace this round so we start learning which of them we can lean on going forward.

I’d be happiest keeping Alice and Charlie together for this one and adding someone like Bob or Frank as the third. I’d rather hold off on putting Grace on a mission just yet until we have a bit more to go on from the table.

I don’t love auto-locking both Alice and Charlie just because of one clean mission; I’d rather see something like Alice plus two new people (including me) so we actually start getting info on more than the same pair.
I’d rather not auto-include both Alice and Charlie again; something like Alice, Grace, and me feels like a good balance of keeping one “proven” member while actually testing some new people.

I don’t think we should lock in both Alice and Charlie again, but I do like keeping exactly one of them and pairing with two people we haven’t seen yet—something like Alice, Frank, and me would give us useful new info.

proposals.reasoning: Alice and Charlie have been on both successful missions so far with no fails, so keeping that core preserves our most reliable track record. However, repeatedly auto-locking Alice/Charlie/Diana gives us almost no information about the rest of the table, which several players (including me) have already raised concerns about. By swapping just one slot—replacing Diana with me—we keep the proven Alice/Charlie core while introducing a single new variable. If this team succeeds, it further reinforces trust in Alice and Charlie and starts to clear me; if it fails, we get a very sharp information point about where to focus suspicion between the new addition and the existing core, instead of staying in the dark about everyone outside the original trio.

votes.comment: At 2–0 we should prioritize the safest repeat of the fully clean Alice/Charlie/Diana trio; adding Eve introduces unnecessary risk when we’re one mission from victory.
We’re one mission from winning, so we should minimize risk and rerun the fully clean Alice/Charlie/Diana team instead of introducing a new unknown like Eve.
Alice and I have a perfect track record so far, and adding just one new person (Eve) keeps the core while giving useful info; the team is still likely mostly good and the risk at 2–0 is acceptable.
We’re already 2–0 with Alice/Charlie/Diana and no fails; swapping out a proven member for an untested one on a potential game-winning mission is unnecessary risk.
I’m on the team and can influence the outcome; rejecting risks a clean good win without me involved.
Highly likely to be a mostly-good team that could win the game if it succeeds; I’d rather not lock in the proven Alice/Charlie core again without adding new, untested players.

At 2–0 for good, we can’t afford another totally untested mix—either keep the fully proven Alice/Charlie/Diana trio or rotate in someone who’s actually been pushing for information like Frank or me, rather than a single new variable that still leaves most of the table unread.

proposals.reasoning: We’ve had two clean missions with Charlie as part of the core, so I want to keep Charlie as the anchor for stability, but I agree with the concerns that auto-locking Alice/Charlie/Diana gives us almost no new information about the rest of the table. By adding both me and Grace, we break out of the established block and get concrete info on two players who haven’t been on a mission yet, while still retaining one trusted element in Charlie. If this team succeeds, it strongly increases trust in both new additions; if it fails, we immediately know that at least one of Frank/Grace is bad, which is far more informative than rerunning the same trio again.

votes.comment: We’re 2–0 with the Alice/Charlie (+Diana) core; swapping in two completely untested players when we only need one more success is unnecessarily risky.
At 2–0 we should prioritize the safest path to victory; replacing the proven Alice/Charlie/Diana core with two untested players on a potential game-winning mission is too risky.

At 2–0 we should prioritize the highest chance of a clean third success, not experimentation; swapping in two untested players (including Grace, who is riskier from my info) is less safe than rerunning the proven Alice/Charlie/Diana trio.
This drops the only fully proven trio and brings in two completely untested players at once; I’d rather stick closer to the Alice/Charlie/Diana core or only rotate one slot at a time for safer info.
We’re down 0–2, so we need a fail now; this lineup likely contains at least one evil, and blocking every non-core variation just hands good an easy third clean mission eventually.
I’m on this team and know at least one other evil is too, so this is our best shot to sabotage and prevent an instant good win at 3-0.
Both Frank and I are on it, so it guarantees evil has strong influence and a chance to sabotage while still looking consistent with our earlier info-gathering stance.

proposals.reasoning: Alice and Charlie have been on both previous missions, which were both clean successes, so keeping that proven core maintains continuity. I’ve been advocating against auto-locking the exact same trio to avoid flying blind on the rest of the table, so swapping Diana for me gives us new information while still relying on the successful Alice/Charlie backbone. This balances stability with the need to test an additional player without completely abandoning what’s worked so far.

votes.comment: Alice/Charlie/Diana is the only fully proven trio; swapping in Grace over Diana is unnecessary risk when we can still propose the same clean team.
Alice/Charlie have a perfect, double-tested track record; adding Grace gives new info while keeping the most likely-good core intact.
Keeps the proven Alice/Charlie core from two clean missions while adding Grace (who I strongly want tested) instead of repeating the exact same trio.
I’d rather stick with the fully clean Alice/Charlie/Diana trio than swap in an untested player when we’re already up 2–0.

If Alice and Charlie are both good, adding an untested Grace has a real chance of giving good a clean 3rd success and ending the game; I’d rather push for a team that includes me so evil can guarantee a fail instead of gambling here.
Our side is represented on this team, and we need a chance to sabotage since good is one success away from winning.
I’m on the team and it still keeps the proven Alice/Charlie core while adding new info, so I’m fine sending this.

discussion.content: Given we’re 2-for-2 with teams that always included Charlie and me (and last time also Diana), I strongly prefer we keep that core—Alice, Charlie, and Diana—unless someone has a really compelling reason to break up a fully clean track record.

Given we’ve had two clean runs with Alice and Charlie (and Diana once), I’m inclined to keep that core together for this mission. If we change anything, I’d only swap around the third slot, but right now I’m fine with Alice/Charlie/Diana going again.
Sticking with the proven Alice/Charlie/Diana trio makes the most sense to me right now—at 2–0, I don't see a good reason to introduce new uncertainty.

Given how early it still is and that Alice/Charlie/Diana have a perfect record with no fails, I’d rather not introduce new variables on a 3-person mission. I’m good with running that same team back one more time.

I get why everyone likes the Alice/Charlie/Diana trio, but auto-locking the same core every time makes it really hard to get new info—I'd rather see at least one slot rotate so we’re not flying blind about the rest of the table.

I get the appeal of just rerunning Alice/Charlie/Diana, but I’m with Eve that we need some info, so I’d rather keep Charlie as the constant and rotate at least one slot—ideally adding someone new like me this round.

I’m uneasy about auto-running Alice/Charlie/Diana again—if that block is actually hiding evil, we learn nothing—so I’d rather keep Charlie as the anchor and rotate at least one spot to include someone new like Frank or me. That gives us actual information instead of just trusting the same trio on momentum.

proposals.reasoning: Alice/Charlie/Diana is the only trio we’ve seen twice with two clean successes, which strongly suggests that if there is any evil among them, they’ve passed up multiple chances to sabotage. The only failed mission was when Grace replaced Diana (team Alice/Charlie/Grace), making Grace the most suspicious addition so far. For the fourth slot, it’s best to add a completely untested player rather than recycle Grace; Bob has been active in discussion but has not been on any mission yet, so including Bob both keeps the trusted core intact and gives us new information about an untested player.

votes.comment: Core of Alice/Charlie/Diana is our most tested group with two clean missions; keeping Grace off after the only fail and adding untested Bob is a reasonable balance of safety and information.

Alice/Charlie/Diana have two clean missions together and the only fail came when Grace replaced Diana, making Grace the prime suspect. This team most likely has 0 evils if Grace is bad, and even if not, it’s still the safest available option.
Core of Alice/Charlie/Diana has two clean missions; Grace is implicated by the only fail; adding untested Bob gives new info while keeping the trusted trio intact.
Keeps the only twice-successful core (Alice/Charlie/Diana) and adds a new, untested player (Bob) instead of reusing the most suspicious option from the failed mission.
This is the most trusted-looking team right now (the clean A/C/D core plus an untested), which is very dangerous for evil at 2–1; I don’t want such a ‘safe’ team to go through.

Leaning too hard on the same core trio feels risky; I’d rather see one of Alice/Charlie/Diana rotated out for an untested like Eve or Frank so we’re not blindly trusting a fixed block this close to the end.
No evil players are on this team; we need an evil included to have a chance to sabotage and avoid an auto-loss on missions.

discussion.content: Given missions 1 and 2 both passed with me, Charlie, and Diana, I’d like our next team to be that same core three plus one of the untested (not Grace), and I’m especially wary of putting Grace back on a mission right now.

Given the two clean missions with Alice, Charlie, and Diana, I think we should stick with that core and add one of Bob/Eve/Frank—but definitely keep Grace off the team for now. If we’re forced to choose, I’d lean toward adding someone who hasn’t been on any mission yet so we get new info.

Sticking with the Alice/Charlie/Diana core makes sense to me since that’s our only fully clean, repeated combo, and I’d add one of Bob/Eve/Frank who hasn’t been on a mission yet for extra info. I’m strongly against putting Grace back on the team right after a fail.

I’m comfortable sticking with the Alice/Charlie/Diana core since it’s the only combo we’ve seen twice and both were clean, and for the fourth I’d rather test Bob or Frank than risk putting Grace straight back on after a fail. Between them, I slightly prefer adding Bob this round so we at least get some info on someone who’s been talking but not yet tested.

I get that everyone likes the Alice/Charlie/Diana core, but two clean missions don’t *prove* all three are good—Grace being auto-flagged off one fail feels a bit too easy. I’d still lean toward testing someone new like Bob or Frank, but I’d also keep an open mind that the problem on Mission 3 might not have been Grace alone.

I get why everyone’s defaulting to the Alice/Charlie/Diana core, and I’m fine sticking with that for now, but I’d really like to see myself (Frank) on this mission so we get actual info on someone completely untested instead of just auto-blaming Grace off a single fail.

Given how hard everyone’s locking onto the Alice/Charlie/Diana core, I’m a bit nervous we’re just letting a coordinated pair skate by, but I get that I’m an easy suspicion after Mission 3, so I’m fine sitting this one out if it means we at least add a truly untested like Bob or Frank instead of autopiloting.

evil_discussion.content: I’m most convinced Diana is Merlin: she was weirdly wary of Grace from Mission 2 onward *before* there was any mission evidence against her, but never really pushed suspicion onto Eve or Frank specifically, which fits someone who knows exactly one of the evils and is “safely” tunneling there. Alice’s push for the Alice/Charlie/Diana core feels more like momentum logic than hidden knowledge, and Bob/Charlie both read more like cautious vanilla good than someone quietly steering away from us with intent.

I’m largely with Eve that Diana is the best Merlin candidate: from Mission 2 on she kept this oddly “cautious but consistent” distance from Grace without ever seriously probing Eve or me, which feels like someone who already knows roughly where the rot is and is choosing the safest, most public scapegoat. Alice’s hard commitment to the Alice/Charlie/Diana core reads like a confident good leader riding results, and Charlie/Bob both feel more like reactive, incremental villagers than someone quietly protecting specific people.

I’m with you both that Diana is the standout Merlin pick: from Mission 2 onward she was *pre-emptively* skittish about me before there was any mechanical reason, but stayed conspicuously non-committal on Eve and Frank even when it would’ve been “balanced” to spread suspicion. Alice’s insistence on the Alice/Charlie/Diana core reads like a confident villager riding results, while Bob and Charlie both feel like cautious, info-hungry vanilla goods rather than someone quietly shielding specific players.

assassin_phase.reasoning: From Mission 2 onward, Diana showed a consistent, pre-emptive wariness of Grace before there was any mission evidence against her, which fits someone who secretly knows at least one evil. At the same time, she carefully avoided strongly suspecting Eve or Frank, maintaining a cautious but non-accusatory stance toward them that looks like Merlin trying not to reveal full knowledge while still guiding the table away from the real threats.
